snippet: Sporadic cocaine users tend to have a larger frontal lobe, a region associated with self-control, while cocaine addicts are more likely to have small frontal lobes even before they start using drugs, a new study finds.
abstract: Dr Karen Ersche study in journal Biological Psychiatry suggests that people with smaller frontal lobe regions in their brains, area associated with self-control, are more at risk for cocaine addiction.
lead_paragraph: Sporadic cocaine users tend to have a larger frontal lobe, a region associated with self-control, while cocaine addicts are more likely to have small frontal lobes even before they start using drugs, a new study finds.

headline.main: Brain Shape Linked to Cocaine Addiction
